The Silane system incorporates several preventative actions that ensure a safe and leak free system.



All Silane handling is performed per written standard operating procedure by trained employees. The Silane system is not modified except through management of change process. Preventative maintenance is performed on the Silane system. Ready for Startup Review is performed after significant maintenance / alteration to system. Process hazards are identified and mitigation verified by process hazard analysis.



A visual inspection of the Silane system is carried out prior to each use of the system. Silane leakage will leave a white or brownish type staining (silicon dioxide powder) on the system components when the Silane comes in contact with air. Following the visual inspection a leak check is performed with high-pressure helium to the working pressure of the system. A final system check is the vacuum leak check. In this test the system must hold a certain level of vacuum for a specified amount of time in order to be certified leak-free.





When the transfer of Silane is taking place from the bulk source only the required amount of bulk Silane is valved open to the system, minimizing the amount of Silane that could potentially escape should a leak occur and reducing the amount of time an operator would need to isolate the bulk source of  Silane. The Silane operation is constantly monitored while the system is in use. At the end of each workday all sources of Silane are closed off and isolated.





All Silane filling is monitored by both weight and pressure using calibrated scales and gauges. This cross-reference between weight and pressure minimizes the possibility of an overfill condition to occur.





The Silane system is constructed with a minimal amount of threaded connections and is welded wherever possible. All piping material is 316L stainless steel. All valves on the Silane system incorporate a double seal design and offer the highest leak free integrity. Emergency shutdown buttons are strategically placed and allow the operator to quickly stop the flow of product should an emergency situation arise.





The greatest hazard of Silane is flammable potential. Silane is a pyrophoric gas that burns upon contact with air. Operators wear personal protective equipment including flame resistant clothing. The Silane filling system is in a Class 1, Division II room. Fire detection/suppression systems are in place at the fill system and bulk source. The bulk source is staged in an area surrounded on three sides with fire walls.

The Hydrogen Chloride Filling System incorporates several preventative actions that ensure a safe and leak free system.



All Hydrogen Chloride handling is performed per written standard operating procedure by trained employees. The Hydrogen Chloride system is not modified except through management of change process. Preventative maintenance is performed on the Hydrogen Chloride system. Ready for Startup Review is performed after significant maintenance / alteration to system. Process hazards are identified and mitigation verified by process hazard analysis.





On a daily basis the operator performs a visual inspection of the Hydrogen Chloride system looking for any signs of leakage which would be indicated with signs of corrosion, discoloration of system parts, or fuming. As part of the standard operating procedure, the system is subjected to a pressure test with helium up to the working pressure of the system to verify the system is leak free prior to any introduction of Hydrogen Chloride into the system.





The Hydrogen Chloride bulk source is a tube trailer consisting of 6 tubes. During use, only one tube is allowed to be open at a time.  The hydrogen chloride is withdrawn from the tube trailer gas phase and not liquid phase. At the end of each workday all tubes on the Hydrogen Chloride trailer are closed (isolated).





Hydrogen Chloride is a corrosive product. The entire fill system is constructed of 316L stainless and hastelloy components, offering resistance to hydrogen chloride corrosion.





The weight of hydrogen chloride cylinders or ton units being filled is monitored as part of standard operating procedure using scales maintained under a calibration program. Weight monitoring prevents cylinders or ton units from a possible overfill condition.

The Chlorine purification and transfilling system consists of a bulk source of industrial grade chlorine (ton container), chlorine purification setup, and a ton unit of purified chlorine product. The purified chlorine product is filled into different sizes of cylinders upon request of customers.  



The Chlorine system incorporates several preventative actions that ensure a safe and leak free system.





All Chlorine handling is performed per written standard operating procedure by trained employees. The Chlorine system is not modified except through management of change process. Preventative maintenance is performed on the Chlorine system. Ready for Startup Review is performed after significant maintenance / alteration to system. Process hazards are identified and mitigation verified by process hazard analysis.





The Chlorine system is given a daily visual inspection prior to use for the purpose of detecting any leaks. Chlorine leaks would be evident from signs of corrosion and/or discoloration of the system parts





As part of the standard operating procedure and prior to each pressurization with hazardous gas, the system is checked for leaks with helium. The system is verified leak free prior to the introduction of Chlorine.





The Chlorine system is constructed of 316L stainless steel and hastelloy components to minimize any corrosion effects from chlorine. The system is primarily of welded connection with a minimal amount of threaded connections used.





The weight of the source and product containers are constantly monitored with calibrated scales to reduce the probability of an overfill condition of the product in the system or in the cylinders being filled.





Operators constantly monitor the process when it is operating. Logs are kept to track the process and analyze the product. 





The Chlorine system is contained entirely inside a process building. This passive mitigation results in a smaller dispersion distance of product should a release ever occur.

Dichlorosilane Program 4 Prevention Program Description:



The Dichlorosilane (DCS) transfilling system consists of a ton unit as bulk source, a cylinder as product receiver and DCS transfilling manifold. The DCS is transfilled from the ton unit into a product cylinder through the manifold in hoods F-11 and F-13 individually.  As part of the DCS production process, a certain number of DCS bulk containers are stored outside of the buildings at different designated areas, where they are separated from other products by a distance for safety purposes. 

 

The DCS system incorporates several preventative actions that ensure a safe and leak free system.

All DCS handling is performed per written standard operating procedure by trained employees. The DCS system is not modified except through management of change process. Preventative maintenance is performed on the DCS system. Ready for Startup Review is performed after significant maintenance/alteration to system. Process hazards are identified and mitigation verified by process hazard analysis.



The DCS system is given a daily visual inspection prior to use for the purpose of detecting any leaks.  



As part of the standard operating procedure and prior to each pressurization with flammable gas, the system is checked for leaks with helium. The system is verified leak free prior to the introduction of DCS.



The DCS system is constructed of 316L stainless steel and hastelloy components to minimize any possible corrosion effects from DCS. The system is primarily of welded connection with a minimal amount of threaded connections used.



The weight of the bulk source is constantly monitored with calibrated scale to reduce the probability of an overfill of the cylinder which is being filled.

 Operators constantly monitor the process when it is operating. Logs are kept to track the process and analyze the product.



The bulk source of DCS is contained inside a process building and DCS product receiving cylinder is contained a designated hood.  This passive mitigation results in a smaller dispersion distance of product should a release ever occur.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:



Risk Management Plan executive summary to comply with 40 CRF ? 68.155 as amended by [61 FR 31726, June 20, 1996, as amended at 69 FR 18831, Apr. 9, 2004].



Location: Air Liquide Electronics US LP, 19 Steel Road West, Morrisville, PA 19067



THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE STATIONARY SOURCE:

Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP is committed to: endorsing the principles of Safety First and Zero Accidents, operating safely and reliably in compliance with all applicable laws, performing in an environmentally responsible manner, consistently producing products and services that meet or exceed our customer's expectations, driving continual improvement and innovation & effectively applying lessons learned.



Air Liquide is a member of the American Chemistry Council (ACC) with a commitment to meet all the code requirements of the Responsible Care Program.



The Morrisville plant complies with Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP (ALEUS) policies on process design to reduce probability of release or accident, risk assessment for new and existing processes, incident investigation and reporting, management of change, ready for startup review, preventive maintenance, and training as accidental release prevention.



The Morrisville plant maintains, follows, and trains personnel on an Emergency Action Plan.



THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:



The Air Liquide Morrisville, PA plant primary activity is transfer of product from a bulk source into compressed gas cylinders. This type of activity is commonly referred to as repackaging. The covered processes at the Morrisville Plant are chlorine re-packaging, hydrogen chloride re-packaging,silane re-packaging, and dichlorosilane repackaging.



THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

The chemical specific accidental release and accident prevention steps are those to mitigate risk from toxic and flammabl

e gases.



This facility complies with EPAs accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. 



Air Liquide Morrisville location utilizes the following accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source:



a) Management of change to ensure the covered process is not altered without a safety review

b) Operation following written operating procedures

c) Training in the process for all operators

d) Preventative maintenance

e) Pre-startup safety review

f) Near miss and incident investigation with corrective and preventative actions

g) Hazard review by process hazard analysis procedure

h) Use of pressure vessels covered under DOT

i) Area electrical classification and conforming equipment

j) Hazard communication (OSHA Hazcomm)

k) Safety program with monthly meetings

l) Hot work program

m) Safe work program



Air Liquide Morrisville location utilizes the following chemical specific prevention steps at the stationary source:

a) Leak checking equipment prior to operation per standard operating procedure

b) Scrubbers to mitigate chemical discharge

c) Pressure relief devices as specified by DOT and/or ASME

d) Hazardous gas monitoring and supervised alarms

e) Process hazard identification by process hazard analysis

f) Check valves 

g) Fire detectors, sprinklers and alarms

h) Operating by following written operating procedures

i) Emergency action plan training

j) Operating and maintenance training

k) Management of change for all changes

l) Lockout followed (safe work program)

m) Burst disc

n) Ventilation

o) Preventative maintenance

p) Pressure gauges

q) Housekeeping

r) Personal protective equipment



THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:



Air Liquide Morrisville location has never had an accident involving chlorine, hydrogen chloride, silane, or dichlorosilane that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in pl

ace.



THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM: 



The Morrisville location maintains its own team of emergency responders to handle emergencies involving chemical release.  At the plant, a stand alone building has been designated as a command post center where ER equipment is stored and emergencies can be managed. The building also contains the key contact information to communicate to outside agencies and local authorities.  The Emergency Response Team members have completed their initial 40 hour training requirement and also receive their annual required 8 hour refresher training.   Plant communicates with the Bucks County Emergency Management, the Bucks County LEPC and the Morrisville Fire Department.   The Fire Department's most recent visit was in November 2018.



The Morrisville Plant maintains a facility Emergency Action Plan that has been shared with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). The plan details the essential actions to take should an emergency occur.    Plant personnel conduct periodic drills. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:



The Morrisville plant plans on:

1) Increasing labeling of process piping; 

2) Reviewing and revising the facility mechanical integrity procedure; and,

3) Replacing Scrubber #7.
